I like this explanation, because people claim that this implies that electrons are in more than one place at a time.  No, they're not, and no experiment has ever shown this.  Instead, as stated in the video, the location of a particular particle is unpredictable until the wave is somehow collapsed by some yet unknown mechanism.  

Particles might be in multiple places at once, but current experiments don't prove this or even suggest it.  

Note that a "wave function" as stated is not like a "wave" that you would encounter at a beach.  All a wave is is a probability distribution of where in space the particle is most likely to be based on its initial location (such as an electron gun).

But this is merely the Bohm interpretation of quantum mechanics, which assumes the existence of an actual particle at all times.  Yet the standard Copenhagen Convention model contradicts this description:  it asserts that the particulate aspect only exists when measurement is made; and that, while the wave aspect exists during motion, there is no particle at all.  The particle suddenly jumps back into existence as the wave "collapses", and at that moment of measurement, there is no longer a wave at all.  Also, there are other interpretations --the Many Worlds interpretation says that the single particle does continue to exist, but that it exists at every point along the wave simultaneously.  Even more strangely, when measurement is made, we only see one particle because all the other particles have continued on within other universes ("worlds") not accessible to us.  Then there is the Cramer Interpretation, along with a myriad of others.  Thus, it is misleading to say that there is a simple explanation of how the transition is made between particle and wave.  In fact, it is one of the great mysteries of quantum physics which, perhaps, can never be solved.  This is why physicists through up their hands and invented the term "wavicle" to denote that the "entity" is both particle and wave and also neither.  (And now that the "string" has replaced the "particle"; does that mean the new duality is "string/wave"?  Should we now be speaking of "straves"?  This last point, I admit, I do not understand.  (Someone enlighten me on this one, btw.)

Hang on. If I hit a note on the piano the sound travels as a wave and yes I pick it up as a single note ..but .. that same wave will supply a note to every other ear in the vicinity. Are we making a big error in perception here? Are we thinking of the wave as carrying the particle when we should understand the particle is a creation of the receiver. It is the receiver that converts the information/energy carried by the wave into a particle/mass. It doesn't matter one jot how many slits the wave travels through. Waves are waves. The particle is not the wave - it is only registered as a particle by the receiver. Of course, if you go interfering with the information in the wave by hitting it with a counter beam then the information is going to change, isn't it? If this still doesn't make sense then read this: there exists a position/momentum uncertaintity relation. Can a particle localize completily in position? Sure! Then the particle graph would be just one point and abolutely not a wave in sight. But the momentum graph would look like a plastering of waves completely delocalized. Interactions may rotate the particle so it's completely particle like in momentum and wavy in position (or something in between) but never completely both at the same time!

What I am getting at with this is that the wavy nature of particles always exists. This is proven with the uncertainty relation; go completely particle like with one observable (say E) and the other related trait will be completely wavy (say time). 
Saying that an electron is riding on a wave in not simplified it is absolutely wrong and has been proven false by a multitude of experiments.

This is false particles are absolutely not guided by waves. Particle's get there particle like properties from Eigenstates (or at least highly localized) of waves. There is no such thing as electrons riding around on waves. 

Example: If E is a particular possible value for a particle (an eigenstate) then time is infinite. Therefore the particle's in stable state and can be there for ever. Stable particles are completely particle like for energy but spread across all time (hence stable).

This is blatantly false, I am afraid.

The "particle" isn't guided by the "wave". There is neither such thing. Electrons are quanta and behave like quanta. "Measurements" are interactions with other quanta, because everything is made of them. Quanta has some mathematical descriptions we know as Quantum Electrodynamics and Gauge Theory.

But let me emphasise that neither reference waves or particles.

That's more along the lines of mutually exclusive quantum behavior of electrons, which is more towards Heisenberg than this video, following Schrodinger's model. The Double Slit is a good example of the duality itself, but the underlying concepts are in fact more difficult and so full of metaphysical implications that its in fact easier to simply use the model of simultaneous wave/particle natures as opposed to a mutually exclusive model.
